pages.text: The noble metal hypothesis has proven to be true and I was able to get some new results from my observations and experiments.$(br2)Most importantly, a rock thrown into an excess of the tear fluid have almost instantly turned into a handful of sludge.
Unfortunately, this sludge seems rather mundane. I wonder if more exotic materials can yield more promising results?$(br2)

However, the way tears interacted with stone seem rather remarkable.$(br2)At first, the fluids soaks into cracks and crevices making them glow; a moment later, the whole stone starts to dimly glow and shortly after it just crumbles apart.

Another thing that the experiment had shown is that touching the fluid is$(o)unimaginably painful$().$(br2)The main outtake so far is that I need a more controllable way of studying tear interactions instead of just throwing stuff into a crucible.$(br2)todo: infusion table...
